Article Title: US travel ban hits top talent: Iranian biologist with more than 200 citations forced to abandon Harvard postdoc
Article Text:
Top talent caught in the US‚ÄìIran conflict





How the 2025 travel ban changed the rules

‚ÄòMuslims Sucking Our Resources‚Äô: Republican Andy Ogles Tells Trump To Deport All Muslim Immigrants

Rushing to outrun a policy shift

A forced pivot to Canada

Innovation versus immigration politics

Living with permanent uncertainty









For nearly a year, Delaram Pouyabahar planned her next academic step around a postdoctoral position at Harvard University. Interviews, fellowship applications, visa paperwork and a consular interview in Toronto were all completed. Then, in early June 2025, a new US travel ban quietly brought those plans to a halt.The policy, announced on June 4, expanded the scope of the 2017 travel ban to 19 countries, including Iran. Unlike the earlier ban, which still allowed many students and academic researchers to enter the US after delays or special approvals, the new rules removed those pathways altogether. According to Pouyabahar‚Äôs own public account, her visa process simply stalled after the ban took effect, leaving her unable to take up the Harvard postdoc she had spent months preparing for.Pouyabahar is not an obscure or early stage applicant. She is an Iranian born computational biologist specialising in machine learning methods for single cell RNA sequencing, a fast growing area at the intersection of AI and life sciences. One of her Nature journal papers has been cited more than 200 times, an unusually high figure for an early career researcher and a marker of broad influence within the field.Her work focuses on developing tools that help scientists interpret complex biological data, methods that are now used by research groups worldwide.In a global academic system that prizes measurable impact, citation counts and journal quality, her profile places her among the most competitive candidates for elite postdoctoral positions.The 2025 travel ban goes further than its 2017 predecessor. While the earlier policy eventually allowed exemptions for F and J visas covering students, postdoctoral researchers and visiting scholars, the new version offers no such carve outs. New entries from affected countries are blocked regardless of academic credentials or institutional sponsorship.Higher education associations and university immigration offices estimate that thousands of prospective students and scholars, potentially more than 10,000, could be affected by the policy. At institutions such as Harvard, administrators have warned that dozens of incoming researchers from banned countries may be unable to take up their positions.When draft versions of the ban appeared in media reports in March 2025, Pouyabahar attempted to accelerate her timeline. She rescheduled her PhD defence at short notice, preparing in just two weeks in the hope that an earlier completion date might protect her plans.Those efforts proved futile. The ban was announced only weeks after her visa interview, and she has said she never received a response. When she asked about the possibility of an exemption, she was told it was unlikely to help under the new policy framework.With the US option closed, Pouyabahar redirected her career to Canada, where she was already based and where immigration pathways for researchers remain more predictable. The move allowed her to continue her work, but it came at the cost of abandoning a carefully planned transition to one of the world‚Äôs most prestigious research environments.Her experience reflects a broader pattern among Iranian scholars affected by the ban. Many have quietly rerouted their careers to Canada or Europe, while others have delayed projects, lost funding opportunities or put academic plans on hold altogether.Economists and science policy researchers have consistently shown that high skilled immigrants play an outsized role in US innovation. Foreign born scientists account for a disproportionate share of patents, startups and breakthrough research, particularly in fields such as biotechnology and artificial intelligence.Critics argue that policies which exclude researchers like Pouyabahar undermine America‚Äôs scientific and economic competitiveness. Supporters of the ban frame it as a national security measure. What stands out, however, is how muted the political and public response has been compared with the airport protests and legal battles that followed the 2017 travel ban.Beyond the immediate career impact, Pouyabahar has described the psychological toll of the process, pointing to months of uncertainty over visa status, the risk of frozen grants and the constant fear of sudden policy changes.Reflecting on the outcome, she has said that in the current political climate she feels a sense of reluctant relief at not entering a system where immigration status can be overturned overnight. For her and many others, the experience has reshaped how they view the US as a destination for building a scientific career.

Her work focuses on developing tools that help scientists interpret complex biological data. The 2025 travel ban goes further than its 2017 predecessor. While the earlier policy eventually allowed exemptions for F and J visas covering students, postdoctoral researchers and visiting scholars, the new version offers no such carve outs.

The visa officers are also keeping the passports of the candidates which, according to Reddit, is a sign that the request will be approved sooner -- if the officer returns to passport, many believe the request may take two to three months.A 221(g) slip is a notice given by a US consular officer after a visa interview saying your visa cannot be approved right now under Section 221(g) of the U.S. Immigration and Nationality Act. It does not mean a denial‚Äîit means the case is temporarily refused pending more action. But now everyone is getting this slip. It means additional documents are needed or the case requires administrative processing or some clarification is required.The slip comes in various colors and now almost all candidates are getting white slip. There is no standard meaning of the colors worldwide and they may vary from consulate to consulate but after social media vetting started, the standard meaning the 221(g) slip conveys is that the decision is pending for social media vetting.According to immigration experts, the color of the slip does not determine the outcome, the written instructions do.For social media vetting, H-1B and H-4 visa appointments have been deferred all of a sudden and the H-1Bs of India were the worst hit. Many Indian H-1Bs flew to India to attend their visa stamping in India only to find that the date has been deferred to April, May next year. And those who can't enter the US without a new stamping are now stuck in India, fearing for their jobs.
Article Summary: The US State Department started social media vetting on December 15. There is now no immediate approval or rejection of visa appeals and candidates are issued a 221(g) slip. Candidates are also being asked whether they made their social media accounts public and then the visa approval status is updated online.

Conventional approaches falter

Political negotiations get undermined when factions splinter or external events shift local calculations‚Äîsuch as the Taliban‚Äôs victory in Afghanistan.

Economic development efforts in Balochistan are hampered by ongoing violence but are critical to addressing root causes.

Cross-border sanctuaries and international gray zones complicate decisive action.

The challenges Pakistan faces today are often described in binary terms ‚Äî a threat here, a conflict there ‚Äî but the reality is far more chaotic and intricate, much like the scientific conundrum known as the "three-body problem". This problem, rooted in physics and celestial mechanics, deals with predicting the motions of three gravitational bodies interacting with each other. The paradox is that while two bodies' orbits can be predicted with relative simplicity, introducing a third body creates a system so unstable and non-linear that exact forecasts become practically impossible. Pakistan's existential security dilemmas resemble this dynamic complexity: three powerful, interrelated forces that simultaneously influence and destabilize the country‚Äôs internal and external equilibrium.These three forces are the Taliban , the Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan ( TTP ), and the Baloch insurgency.Individually, each represents a serious security threat. Collectively, their interactions generate overlapping, tangled challenges that confound policy, military strategy, and diplomatic efforts.Recent escalations are a stark reminder of this peril. In October 2025, Pakistan launched airstrikes in Kabul and other Afghan sites targeting TTP leader Noor Wali Mehsud, prompting Taliban retaliation on Pakistani border posts and further Pakistani precision strikes killing dozens of militants.Meanwhile, Baloch attacks surged 53% in 2024 to 938 incidents with over 1,002 fatalities, spilling into 2025 with high-profile hits on CPEC projects.Over 300 attacks rocked Khyber Pakhtunkhwa in 2025 alone, mostly TTP-led.For the first time since 2015, the number of terror attacks in Pakistan crossed the 900-mark.Grasping their interplay is crucial to understanding why Pakistan‚Äôs security apparatus struggles to restore stability ‚Äî and why conventional approaches have so far failed.The Taliban, an Islamist militant group born in Afghanistan in the mid-1990s, rose to international prominence with its capture of Kabul in 1996.Following the US invasion after 9/11, the group was ousted but persisted with insurgency tactics. The Taliban's return to power in Afghanistan in 2021 reshaped regional dynamics and profoundly impacted Pakistan.For Pakistan, the Taliban's ascendance is something of a double-edged sword. On one hand, Islamabad sees the group as a strategic asset to exert influence in Kabul and counter Indian presence in Afghanistan. On the other hand, the Taliban's ideological affinity with Pakistan's own Pashtun tribal regions and cross-border networks complicates Islamabad's control over militancy within its own borders.The Taliban's ideology and governance style also inspire elements within Pakistan, especially in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and the tribal belt. This ideological inspiration runs parallel to fears that the group's Afghan governance failures or hardline policies could spill over, destabilising Pakistan‚Äôs own tribal regions.The Afghan Taliban's 2021 takeover initially promised Pakistan leverage against India, but it backfired spectacularly. Kabul's refusal to dismantle TTP sanctuaries hosting 6,000-6,500 fighters armed with leftover NATO weapons has fueled Islamabad's woes. Tensions peaked in December 2025 with heavy cross-border fire exchanges killing five Afghans, amid soured ties since 2021.Experts like Tahir Khan note the Taliban's inaction strains relations, pushing Pakistan to airstrikes that risk radicalising more TTP factions toward rivals like ISKP. Failed Istanbul peace talks in October 2025 saw Pakistan threaten to "obliterate" the Taliban regime after unmet demands on TTP expulsion. Sirajuddin Haqqani dismissed TTP as Pakistan's "internal matter," vowing forceful responses to violations.This dynamic grants TTP "strategic depth" unparalleled in its history, enabling mergers and centralisation under Mehsud. As analyst Hazrat Ali warns, Pakistani pressure on Kabul could splinter TTP, worsening regional chaos.Pakistan‚Äôs newly appointed armed forces chief Gen. Asim Munir recently called on Afghanistan‚Äôs Taliban government to choose between maintaining ties with Islamabad or supporting the Pakistani Taliban.Munir said that a ‚Äúclear message‚Äù had been delivered to the Taliban government in Kabul: it must decide between Pakistan and ‚ÄúFitna al-Khawarij,‚Äù a term authorities use for the outlawed Pakistani Taliban, known a s Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan.While the Afghan Taliban exerts influence across the border, the Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan represents a homegrown, highly violent insurgency directly challenging the Pakistani state‚Äôs writ. Originating as an umbrella militant organisation around 2007, the TTP embodies a coalition of various Islamist militants and tribal groups united against Islamabad's military operations.The TTP has been responsible for some of the deadliest terrorist attacks in Pakistan over the past decade, targeting military installations, government buildings, schools, and civilian populations. Despite several attempted peace negotiations, the TTP's fractured yet resilient network has shown a capacity to regroup, regrouping largely within the tribal regions of northwestern Pakistan and even spilling across the Afghan border during periods of instability.The group opposes Pakistan‚Äôs state institutions vehemently and views the military, intelligence agencies, and secular political frameworks as existential enemies. Unlike the Afghan Taliban, which now nominally controls Kabul, the TTP pursues a more violent, confrontational agenda rooted in the Pakistani context.The TTP roared back post-Taliban victory. In 2024, it drove over half of 900+ attacks in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, killing 560+, with 67% targeting security forces. By 2025, its operations hit 600+ confrontations, surpassing all of 2024.A stark October 8, 2025, ambush in Kurram killed 11 Pakistani soldiers, including two officers, via roadside bombs and heavy weapons‚Äîexposing border vulnerabilities.TTP now eyes tribal belt control, mirroring Afghan Taliban's path, per CTC West Point analysis. Mehsud's unification of splinters has boosted recruitment, with propaganda invoking Baloch grievances to broaden appeal.Security data shows 96% of attacks in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, blending armed assaults and IEDs, as TTP demands military divestment from businesses. This resurgence, analysts say, stems from Afghan havens, turning Pakistan's past militant proxies into monsters.Simultaneously, Pakistan faces an insurgency in Balochistan‚Äîa sprawling, resource-rich, but underdeveloped southwestern province. The Baloch nationalist movement goes back decades, demanding greater autonomy, resource control, and sometimes outright independence. The insurgency has fluctuated in intensity but remains a persistent thorn in Islamabad‚Äôs side.Baloch militants have targeted Pakistani security forces, infrastructure projects, and economic installations such as the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)‚Äîa flagship regional development initiative. The province's rugged terrain and Baloch tribal dynamics create a challenging environment for Pakistani counterinsurgency efforts.Unlike the religious militancy of the Taliban and TTP, the Baloch insurgency is rooted in ethnic nationalism and grievances over political marginalization, economic neglect, and human rights abuses. This ideological and geographical distinctiveness makes it harder for the Pakistani state to craft a unified internal security strategy.Attacks ballooned to 327 sites across 25 districts in 2024, with 80% fatality spike to 1,002+. The March 11, 2025, Jaffar Express hijacking by BLA-Jeeyand killed 26 hostages and kidnapped 400+, showcasing tactical evolution from hit-and-runs to coordinated ops.CPEC remains prime target: Operation Dara-e-Bolan in January 2024 and March 2025 barrages hit Chinese workers, amid Israel-Iran and India-Pakistan tensions stoking fears of wider nexuses. BLA's sophistication targets BRI, militarizing the region further.Unlike TTP's jihadism, Baloch fights for autonomy, but heavy state crackdowns alienate locals, per CTC analysis. Injuries rose to 689, property losses to 546, signaling expanded reach despite counter-ops killing 76 insurgents.Here lies Pakistan‚Äôs three-body problem: the Taliban, TTP, and Baloch insurgency don‚Äôt operate in isolation.Their influences collide, interact, and ripple across Pakistan‚Äôs geopolitical landscape in unpredictable ways.Traditional counterinsurgency and counterterrorism strategies rely on clear, identifiable enemies that can be neutralised through military might, intelligence operations, or negotiated settlements. The three-body dynamic, however, forces Pakistan to wrestle with fluid, overlapping, and at times contradictory challenges.In essence, each "body" in this problem pulls Pakistan‚Äôs security landscape in different directions, making any single policy or operation insufficient.Addressing this three-body problem requires Pakistan to adopt a holistic, integrated strategy that acknowledges the distinct yet intertwined nature of these challenges.Pakistan's military has intensified operations since mid-2025 to counter the Taliban-TTP-Baloch nexus, focusing on intelligence-based strikes (IBOs), cross-border actions, and sustained ground campaigns amid over 1,000 attacks nationwide. These efforts emphasize decapitation of TTP leadership, border denial, and Baloch insurgency suppression, though resource strains from multi-front threats limit gains.The army launched precision airstrikes into Afghanistan targeting TTP hideouts. On October 9, 2025, raids hit Kabul, Khost, Jalalabad, and Paktika, aiming at TTP chief Noor Wali Mehsud's headquarters, killing dozens of militants despite his survival claim. Retaliatory Taliban attacks on border posts prompted further Pakistani strikes on October 11-12, neutralizing Taliban brigades and TTP operatives.Recent IBOs in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa yielded kills: December 5-6 saw nine TTP fighters eliminated in Tank and Lakki Marwat districts. September 13 clashes in South Waziristan and Lower Dir killed 35 militants but cost 19 soldiers, highlighting ambush risks. December 6-7 Chaman border strikes destroyed three Taliban bases, killing 23 fighters after ceasefire violations.Operation Azm-e-Istehkam, ramped up in summer 2025, reports near-daily TTP neutralizations in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, addressing a terrorism surge to highest levels since 2015.In Balochistan, May 2025 operations deployed over 40 vehicles in Surab, Zehri, and Khuzdar, declaring areas "sensitive" to hunt Baloch Liberation Army (BLA) amid 70+ attacks under Operation Herof. August 30 actions post-BLA civilian strikes killed five insurgents and captured two in Kech, part of Azm-e-Istehkam's escalation.Security forces targeted BLA convoys, camps, and intelligence squads, seizing arms despite BLA claims of 25 blockades and 15 camp captures in 2024-2025. These ops focus on CPEC protection, countering 938 incidents with 1,002 fatalities in 2024 extending into 2025.The ongoing volatility reveals that no single strategy will yield a definitive victory; instead, Pakistan must adopt nuanced, integrated policies that combine hard military pressure with political dialogue, regional diplomacy, and socioeconomic inclusion.The future of Pakistan‚Äôs sovereignty and regional peace depends on how skillfully it navigates this chaotic three-body problem, turning a disordered struggle into a managed equilibrium before the forces pull the nation into further unrest and fragmentation.
Article Summary: Pakistan‚Äôs western tribal belt and Balochistan both border Afghanistan and Iran, turning these regions into transnational conflict zones. There is evidence of ideological and tactical cross-pollination between the Afghan Taliban and the TTP. The Baloch insurgency, while largely ethnonationalist, has occasionally sought indirect or tactical alliances with other groups to magnify its impact.

Article Title: Pakistan ex-ISI chief jailed: Faiz Hameed convicted after court martial; handed 14 years in prison
Article Text:
Uncertainty Over Pakistan‚Äôs Top Military Post Could Trigger Conflict: Analyst





A Pakistani military court has sentenced former inter-services intelligence (ISI) director general Lt Gen (retd) Faiz Hameed to 14 years in prison after a 15-month-long court-martial on multiple charges, including political interference and violations of the official secrets act.The Field General Court Martial, held under the Pakistan army act, found Hameed guilty on four counts - engaging in political activities, misuse of authority and state resources, violation of the official secrets act, and causing wrongful loss to individuals. The military did not identify who suffered such losses. Officials said Hameed was provided full legal rights and representation during the proceedings. He retains the right to appeal.Hameed, once considered a close confidant of jailed former prime minister Imran Khan , had been detained in 2024 after an internal investigation linked to the Top City housing project near Islamabad. Until Thursday's announcement, neither the charges nor details of the probe had been formally disclosed by the government or the military.Security analyst Syed Muhammad Ali told AP that the verdict followed ‚Äúa lengthy investigation that gave the former ISI chief ample opportunity to defend himself.‚ÄùHe added: ‚ÄúThe decision signals the military leadership‚Äôs intent that no officer, regardless of rank, will be allowed to engage in politics, and Hameed‚Äôs case has been made an example for all retired officers.‚ÄùHameed‚Äôs downfall marks a rare instance of a high-ranking former military official facing such a stiff sentence in Pakistan, where the army holds significant institutional influence and senior-level prosecutions are uncommon.His political proximity to Imran Khan had long drawn attention. Khan - who was ousted in 2022 through a no-confidence vote and has since criticized the military and political leadership for his removal - is serving multiple jail terms on graft and other charges. The military, Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif‚Äôs government and the US have all denied Khan‚Äôs claim that they engineered his exit.
Article Summary: Lt Gen (retd) Faiz Hameed sentenced to 14 years in prison. Convicted on multiple charges, including political interference and violations of the official secrets act. Once considered a close confidant of jailed former prime minister Imran Khan.
